article.title: Protective alleles and precision healthcare in crewed spaceflight
article.abstract: Common and rare alleles are now being annotated across millions of human genomes, and omics technologies are increasingly being used to develop health and treatment recommendations.

sections.introduction: Humankind has entered a new chapter of deep space exploration, with numerous institutions worldwide publicly aspiring toward a sustainable human presence on the Moon and Mars, which is also broadening the diversity of humans in space.
sections.results: Growing evidence indicates that spaceflight can elicit a range of stressful and adaptive physiological responses on the human body.
sections.discussion: In the foreseeable future, collecting, storing, and sharing omics data from consenting humans venturing into space for use in research and terrestrially established occupational healthcare strategies also requires careful policy to address a multitude of ethical challenges.

article.insights_summary: This paper reviews published alleles naturally found in human cohorts that have a likely protective effect, which is linked to decreased cancer risk and improved bone, muscular, and cardiovascular health.
article.acknowledgments: The authors thank Sergey Ponomarev (IBMP Russian Academy of Sciences), Raúl Herranz (Centro de Investigaciones Biológicas “Margarita Salas” (CSIC)), Liz Warren (Blue Origin), Ryan T. Scott (KBR; NASA Ames Research Center), Deanne Taylor (University of Pennsylvania), and Richard Barker (University of Wisconsin-Madison).
